verses.text: Save me, O God, for the waters have come up to my neck.
verses.comment: This verse opens with an image of overwhelming trouble. Waters in the Psalms often symbolize chaos and distress (see also Ps 18:16).

verses.text: I sink in deep mire, where there is no standing; I have come into deep waters, and the flood washes over me.
verses.comment: The psalmist emphasizes helplessness, foreshadowing Christ’s suffering as the innocent one overwhelmed by evil (cf. Matt 26:38).

verses.text: I am weary with my crying; my throat is parched. My eyes grow dim while I wait for my God.
verses.comment: This suffering is physical and spiritual. The psalmist’s patience shows trust in God even while longing for deliverance—a virtue seen in the saints.

verses.text: More than the hairs of my head are those who hate me without cause; mighty are those who would destroy me, my enemies who accuse me falsely. What I did not steal, I must restore.
verses.comment: This verse is quoted about Christ in John 15:25. It points to the innocent suffering of Jesus, who was accused without cause.

verses.text: O God, you know my foolishness, and my wrongs are not hidden from you.
verses.comment: The psalmist admits human weakness and sinfulness; Christ, though sinless, took on our sins (cf. 2 Cor 5:21). Confession is vital, as in the Sacrament of Reconciliation.

verses.text: Let not those who hope in you be put to shame because of me, O Lord GOD of armies; let not those who seek you be dishonored because of me, O God of Israel.
verses.comment: He prays that his suffering not lead others astray, hinting at the Church’s unity. The Church is the people of God, the Body of Christ.

verses.text: For it is for your sake that I have borne reproach; dishonor has covered my face.
verses.comment: Suffering for God’s sake is a theme fulfilled in Christ (Rom 15:3) and connects to the Catholic call to unite our sufferings with Christ’s.

verses.text: I have become a stranger to my brothers, an alien to my mother's children.
verses.comment: The Messiah is rejected by his own, foreshadowing Jesus’ rejection by his family and people (John 7:5).

verses.text: For zeal for your house has consumed me, and the insults of those who insult you have fallen on me.
verses.comment: Directly applied to Jesus when He cleanses the Temple (John 2:17). Here is a Messianic prophecy fulfilled in Christ.

verses.text: When I wept and humbled my soul with fasting, it became a reproach for me.
verses.comment: Acts of penance are misunderstood, yet fasting is commended elsewhere (Matt 6:16). Fasting is still central in Catholic life.

verses.text: When I made sackcloth my clothing, I became the byword of them.
verses.comment: Wearing sackcloth is a sign of repentance. The world mocks visible penance, as the saints were often mocked.

verses.text: I am the talk of those who sit in the gate; the drunkards make songs about me.
verses.comment: The righteous suffer ridicule from all levels of society. Christ on the cross was mocked by passersby and leaders alike.

verses.text: But as for me, my prayer is to you, O LORD, at an acceptable time, O God, in the abundance of your mercy, answer me with your faithful salvation.
verses.comment: God hears prayer at the right time (cf. 2 Cor 6:2). The faithful depend on God’s mercy, foundational in Catholic spirituality.

verses.text: Deliver me from the mire, and let me not sink. Let me be delivered from those who hate me, and from the deep waters.
verses.comment: Repetition shows the intensity of distress. Catholic tradition teaches perseverance in prayer during trials.

verses.text: Let not the floodwaters overwhelm me, nor the deep swallow me up, nor the pit close its mouth over me.
verses.comment: Imagery of Sheol (the pit) symbolizes the threat of death and ultimate despair. Christ descends to the dead to rescue souls (Apostles’ Creed).

verses.text: Answer me, O LORD, for your mercy is good; according to the abundance of your steadfast love, turn to me.
verses.comment: The focus on God’s mercy ties to Divine Mercy, a devotion with particular prominence in Catholicism.

verses.text: Do not hide your face from your servant, for I am in trouble; answer me quickly.
verses.comment: Not wanting God to hide His face links to the priestly blessing (Num 6:24–26); the Church continues to offer blessing through the Liturgy.

verses.text: Draw near to my soul, redeem me; ransom me because of my enemies.
verses.comment: Language of redemption finds fulfillment in Christ’s atoning work. The Psalmist seeks, as we do in the Eucharist, union with God.

verses.text: You know my reproach, my shame, and my dishonor; all my adversaries are before you.
verses.comment: Christ bore shame on the Cross. God’s omniscience brings comfort: nothing escapes His sight.

verses.text: Reproach has broken my heart, and I am in despair. I waited for pity, but there was none, and for comforters, but I found none.
verses.comment: This foreshadows Christ’s abandonment in Gethsemane and at the Cross (Matt 26:56; Mark 15:34).

verses.text: They gave me gall for food, and in my thirst they gave me vinegar to drink.
verses.comment: Explicitly fulfilled in the Passion of Christ. This prophecy is one of the clearest Messianic foreshadowings.

verses.text: Let their table before them become a trap, and when they are at peace, let it become a snare.
verses.comment: Paul quotes this of hardened Israel. Tables/altars can become a test: in Catholicism, the Eucharist offers blessing or judgment, depending on disposition.

verses.text: Let their eyes be darkened, so that they cannot see, and make their loins continually to tremble.
verses.comment: A prayer for just judgment, paralleled by Paul in Romans. God allows consequences for hardness of heart—used by God to accomplish His plan.

verses.text: Pour out your indignation upon them, and let your burning anger overtake them.
verses.comment: The Psalm includes imprecatory language, but Christ teaches us to love our enemies (Matt 5:44). Yet, God’s justice is real, and the saints pray for conversion of sinners.

verses.text: May their camp be a desolation; let no one dwell in their tents.
verses.comment: Cited by Peter in Acts 1:20 regarding Judas’s betrayal. Prophetic fulfillment points to Christ’s Passion and the fate of His betrayers.

verses.text: For they persecute him whom you have struck down, and recount the pain of those you have wounded.
verses.comment: God’s providence allows suffering for testing or atonement; Christ is the Suffering Servant wounded for our sins.

verses.text: Add iniquity to their iniquity; let them not enter into your righteousness.
verses.comment: A request for just judgment. In Catholic theology, God’s justice is part of His mercy—He desires all to repent (1 Tim 2:4).

verses.text: Let them be blotted out of the Book of Life; let them not be recorded with the righteous.
verses.comment: The Book of Life is a biblical image of eternal destiny, echoed in Daniel 12:1 and Revelation. The Catholic Church reminds us to persevere in grace.

verses.text: But I am afflicted and in pain; let your salvation, O God, set me on high.
verses.comment: Trust in God’s salvation is central to the Psalm; affliction is not the final word—resurrection follows suffering.

verses.text: I will praise the name of God with a song; I will magnify him with thanksgiving.
verses.comment: Praise and thanksgiving are necessary responses to God’s grace, a theme developed in the Mass—‘Eucharist’ means thanksgiving.

verses.text: This will please the LORD more than an ox or a bull with horns and hooves.
verses.comment: Spiritual worship—praise, thanksgiving, a contrite heart—surpasses mere ritual sacrifice. The New Covenant fulfills the Old in Christ’s self-offering.

verses.text: The humble shall see and be glad; you who seek God, let your hearts revive.
verses.comment: God exalts the lowly. Catholicism emphasizes humility as the foundation of holiness (cf. Mary’s Magnificat, Luke 1:48–52).

verses.text: For the LORD hears the needy and does not despise his people who are prisoners.
verses.comment: God’s special care for the poor and imprisoned, mirrored in Jesus’ ministry, is continued in the Church’s works of mercy.

verses.text: Let heaven and earth praise him, the seas and everything that moves in them.
verses.comment: All creation is called to worship. The cosmic liturgy prefigures the heavenly worship seen in Revelation 5.

verses.text: For God will save Zion and build up the cities of Judah, and they shall dwell there and possess it.
verses.comment: God’s promise to save Zion was understood spiritually by Christians as the building up of the Church, the New Jerusalem (Gal 4:26).

verses.text: The children of his servants shall inherit it, and those who love his name shall dwell in it.
verses.comment: The inheritance belongs to the children—the faithful—who love God. In Catholic tradition, the Church is our spiritual home and inheritance through baptism.
